channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Tupperware’s Sweet Spot Shifts to Indonesia
item.description: As in 1960s America, many Indonesian women stay at home, creating an audience for parties run by women who have begun to sidle past conservative mores and into the work force.
item.dc:creator: By JOE COCHRANE
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Indonesian women at a Tupperware products party last year in Jakarta. Indonesia has become Tupperware’s biggest market, passing Germany.

item.title: Memo From Europe: Germans at the Crux of Crises, but Reluctantly
item.description: Europe’s indispensable nation, at the center of crises over Ukraine and Greece and often uncomfortable with leadership, has had a rocky month.
item.dc:creator: By STEVEN ERLANGER
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel sees the Russian threat, but has rejected a military option in Ukraine.

item.title: Detained American Missionaries Leave Venezuela
item.description: The four missionaries, who were held for three days and questioned by Venezuelan authorities, were on their way home on Saturday.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Mexico Moves to Save Endangered Porpoise
item.description: The government’s new policy bans gillnets for two years across the northern Gulf of California and compensates shrimp fishermen for their lost catch.
item.dc:creator: By ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: Charming and Erratic, a Notorious Afghan Speaks
item.description: Shirin Gul is in the 12th year of a 20-year prison sentence for a killing spree that claimed the lives of 27 men. She says the murders were her lover’s idea.
item.dc:creator: By AZAM AHMED
item.media:credit: Gabriela Maj for The New York Times
item.media:description: Shirin Gul, in a cell of the women’s section of Nangarhar Prison in Jalalabad, Afghanistan, is serving a 20-year sentence.

item.title: Nearly Halted in Sierra Leone, Ebola Makes Comeback by Sea
item.description: Sierra Leone thought it had beaten back the disease, then two fishing boats carrying three infected mariners arrived at a wharf in February.
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.dc:creator: By SHERI FINK

item.title: Yasar Kemal, Master Turkish Novelist and Strident Political Critic, Is Dead
item.description: Mr. Kemal repeatedly clashed with the Turkish state while emerging as his country’s first novelist of global stature.
item.dc:creator: By STEPHEN KINZER

item.title: Fertile Ground for Militancy in Hometown of Jihadi John
item.description: Mohammed Emwazi, better known as Jihadi John, was part of a loose network of young Muslims known as the North London Boys, which has sent dozens of young men to fight abroad.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By KATRIN BENNHOLD
item.media:description: The area in London where Mohammed Emwazi, the Islamic State militant known as Jihadi John, is believed to have once lived.

item.title: Opinion: Make School a Democracy
item.description: Children will learn better. Look at rural Colombia.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID L. KIRP

item.title: Fear Envelops Russia After Killing of Putin Critic Boris Y. Nemtsov
item.description: An old friend recounted hearing the former deputy prime minister tell of dangerous new research on Russian involvement in the Ukraine conflict.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: People remembered opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov on Saturday with a memorial at the site of his killing in central Moscow.

item.title: Fear Envelops Russia After Killing of Putin Critic
item.description: An old friend recounted hearing the former deputy prime minister tell of dangerous new research on Russian involvement in the Ukraine conflict.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW E. KRAMER
item.media:description: People remembered opposition leader Boris Y. Nemtsov on Saturday with a memorial at the site of his killing in central Moscow.

item.title: Pirates Free 4 Fishermen in Somalia
item.description: The four Thais were released after being held for nearly five years, longer than any other hostages seized off the Somali coast.
item.dc:creator: By MOHAMMED IBRAHIM

item.title: Britain, Wary of Sanctions, Adds Pressure to Keep Russian From Buying Energy Unit
item.description: The completion of the deal has been slowed by regulators’ concerns that Mikhail Fridman or his company might be targeted by expanded sanctions on the Russian energy industry stemming from the Ukraine conflict.
item.dc:creator: By STANLEY REED

item.title: U.S. Seeks to Deport Bosnians Over War Crimes
item.description: Immigration officials are moving to deport at least 150 Bosnians living in the United States who they say took part in war crimes in the former Yugoslavia in the 1990s.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: By ERIC LICHTBLAU
item.media:credit: Drew Angerer for The New York Times
item.media:description: Michael MacQueen, of Immigration and Customs Enforcement, with a tactical map of Bosnian Serb forces at Srebrenica.

item.title: Online, American Helps Fuel Attacks in Egypt
item.description: Shahid King Bolsen has used social media to encourage frustrated protesters to attack the corporate interests of the Egyptian Army.
item.dc:creator: By DAVID D. KIRKPATRICK
item.media:description: Shadid King Bolsen from afar challenges Egypt’s military.

item.title: India’s New Budget Aims to Boost Growth
item.description: The first full-year budget of Prime Minister Narendra Modi’s government promised a major increase in public spending on infrastructure and a lowering of the corporate tax rate, but it failed to offer any dramatic reforms.
item.dc:creator: By ELLEN BARRY and NEHA THIRANI BAGRI
item.media:description: People watched as India’s finance minister, Arun Jaitley, unveiled the budget on Saturday.

item.title: Brooklyn Arrests Highlight Challenges in Fighting of ISIS and ‘Known Wolves’
item.description: As officials around the world grapple with the emerging security concerns posed by the Islamic State, the New York case provides one of the first public examples of how officials in the United States are approaching the threat.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: By MARC SANTORA and AL BAKER
item.media:description: The federal courthouse in Brooklyn where Abdurasul Hasanovich Juraboev, 24, and Akhror Saidakhmetov, 19, who were arrested and charged with plotting to join the Islamic State, were arraigned on Feb. 25.

item.title: American Missionaries Are Detained in Venezuela
item.description: The four missionaries, affiliated with a church in North Dakota, were involved in a medical assistance program when they were detained by the Venezuelan authorities this week.
item.dc:creator: By WILLIAM NEUMAN

item.title: Diamond Thief Gets 15 Years in Paris Heist
item.description: A French court concluded that Daoudi Yahiaoui, a convicted drug trafficker, was the brain behind a $100 million diamond heist at a Harry Winston jewelry store in 2008.
item.dc:creator: By DOREEN CARVAJAL

item.title: Former Obama Campaign Aide Now Works to Oust Netanyahu
item.description: Jeremy Bird, a former Obama campaign organizer, has drawn fire from Republicans for his consulting work on an effort to unseat Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu.
item.dc:creator: By JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.media:description: Jeremy Bird, a former Obama campaign organizer, who is advising an effort to oust Benjamin Netanyahu.
